title: The life and death of King Iohn from Mr. William Shakespeares comedies, histories, & tragedies. Published according to the true originall copies.

characters.name: Arthur, Duke of Bretagne, nephew to the king

Chatillon, ambassador from France to King John
Queen Elinor, mother to King John
James Gurney, servant to Lady Faulconbridge
Prince Henry, son to King John

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: But for because he hath not wooed me yet:

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: Not that I haue the power to clutch my hand,

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: When his faire Angels would salute my palme,

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: But for my hand, as vnattempted yet,

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: Like a poore begger, raileth on the rich.

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: Well, whiles I am a begger, I will raile,

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: And say there is no sin but to be rich:

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: And being rich, my vertue then shall be,

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: To say there is no vice, but beggerie:

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: Since Kings breake faith vpon commoditie,

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: Gaine be my Lord, for I will worship thee.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Gone to be married? Gone to sweare a peace?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: False blood to false blood ioyn'd. Gone to be freinds?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Shall {% italic: Lewis %} haue {% italic: Blaunch %}, and {% italic: Blaunch %} those Prouinces?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: It is not so; thou hast mispoke, misheard,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Be well aduis'd, tell ore thy tale againe.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: It cannot be, thou do'st but say 'tis so.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: I trust I may not trust thee, for thy word

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Is but the vaine breath of a common man:

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Beleeue me, I doe not beleeue thee man,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: I haue a Kings oath to the contrarie.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Thou shalt be punish'd for thus frighting me,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: For I am sicke, and capeable of feares,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Opprest with wrongs, and therefore full of feares,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: A widdow, husbandles, subiect to feares,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: A woman naturally borne to feares;

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: And though thou now confesse thou didst but iest

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: With my vext spirits, I cannot take a Truce,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: But they will quake and tremble all this day.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: What dost thou meane by shaking of thy head ?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Why dost thou looke so sadly on my sonne?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: What meanes that hand vpon that breast of thine?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Why holdes thine eie that lamentable rhewme,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Like a proud riuer peering ore his bounds?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Be these sad signes confirmers of thy words?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Then speake againe, not all thy former tale,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: But this one word, whether thy tale be true.

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: As true as I beleeue you thinke them false,

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: That giue you cause to proue my saying true.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Oh if thou teach me to beleeue this sorrow,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Teach thou this sorrow, how to make me dye,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: And let beleefe, and life encounter so,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: As doth the furie of two desperate men,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Which in the very meeting fall, and dye.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: {% italic: Lewes %} marry {% italic: Blaunch %}? O boy, then where art thou?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: {% italic: France %} friend with {% italic: England %}, what becomes of me ?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Fellow be gone: I cannot brooke thy sight,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: This newes hath made thee a most vgly man.

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: What other harme haue I good Lady done,

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: But spoke the harme, that is by others done?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Which harme within it selfe so heynous is,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: As it makes harmefull all that speake of it.

lines.speaker: Ar.
lines.text: I do beseech you Madam be content.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: If thou that bidst me be content, wert grim

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Vgly, and slandrous to thy Mothers wombe,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Full of vnpleasing blots, and sightlesse staines,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Lame, foolish, crooked, swart, prodigious,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Patch'd with foule Moles, and eyeâ€‘offending markes,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: I would not care, I then would be content,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: For then I should not loue thee: no, nor thou

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Become thy great birth, nor deserue a Crowne.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: But thou art faire, and at thy birth (deere boy)

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Nature and Fortune ioyn'd to make thee great.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Of Natures guifts, thou mayst with Lillies boast,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: And with the halfeâ€‘blowne Rose. But Fortune, oh,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: She is corrupted, chang'd, and wonne from thee,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Sh'adulterates hourely with thine Vnckle {% italic: Iohn %},

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: And with her golden hand hath pluckt on France

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: To tread downe faire respect of Soueraigntie,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: And made his Maiestie the bawd to theirs.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: France is a Bawd to Fortune, and king {% italic: Iohn %},

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: That strumpet Fortune, that vsurping {% italic: Iohn %}:

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Tell me thou fellow, is no France forsworne?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: E nvenom him with words, or get thee gone,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: And leaue those woes alone, which I alone

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Am bound to vnderâ€‘beare.

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: Pardon me Madam,

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: I may not goe without you to the kings.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Thou maist, thou shalt, I will not go with thee,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: I will instruct my sorrowes to bee proud,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: For greefe is proud, and makes his owner stoope,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: To me and to the state of my great greefe,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Let kings assemble: for my greefe's so great,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: That no supporter but the huge firme earth

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Can hold it vp: here I and sorrowes sit,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Heere is my Throne, bid kings come bow to it.

lines.speaker: Fran.
lines.text: 'Tis true (faire daughter) and this blessed day,

lines.speaker: Fran.
lines.text: Euer in {% italic: France %} shall be kept festiuall:

lines.speaker: Fran.
lines.text: To solemnize this day the glorious sunne

lines.speaker: Fran.
lines.text: Stayes in his course, and playes the Alchymist,

lines.speaker: Fran.
lines.text: Turning with splendor of his precious eye

lines.speaker: Fran.
lines.text: The meager cloddy earth to glittering gold:

lines.speaker: Fran.
lines.text: The yearely course that brings this day about,

lines.speaker: Fran.
lines.text: Shall neuer see it, but a holy day.

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: A wicked day, and not a holy day.

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: What hath this day deseru'd? what hath it done,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: That it in golden letters should be set

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Among the high tides in the Kalender?

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Nay, rather turne this day out of the weeke,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: This day of shame, oppression, periury.

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Or if it must stand still, let wiues with childe

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Pray that their burthens may not fall this day,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Lest that their hopes prodigiously be crost:

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: But (on this day) let Seaâ€‘men feare no wracke,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: No bargaines breake that are not this day made;

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: This day all things begun, come to ill end,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Yea, faith it selfe to hollow falshood change.

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: By heauen Lady, you shall haue no cause

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: To curse the faire proceedings of this day:

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Haue I not pawn'd to you my Maiesty?

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: You haue beguil'd me with a counterfeit

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Resembling Maiesty, which being touch'd and tride,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Proues valuelesse: you are forsworne, forsworne,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: You came in Armes to spill mine enemies bloud,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: But now in Armes, you strengthen it with yours.

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: The grapling vigor, and rough frowne of Warre

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Is cold in amitie, and painted peace,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: And our oppression hath made vp this league:

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Arme, arme, you heauens, against these periur'd Kings,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: A widdow cries, be husband to me (heauens)

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Let not the howres of this vngodly day

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Weare out the daies in Peace; but ere Sunâ€‘set,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Set armed discord 'twixt these periur'd Kings,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Heare me, Oh, heare me.

lines.speaker: Aust.
lines.text: Lady {% italic: Constance %}, peace.

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: War, war, no peace, peace is to me a warre:

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: O {% italic: Lymoges %}, O {% italic: Austria %}, thou dost shame

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: That bloudy spoyle: thou slaue, thou wretch, y u coward,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Thou little valiant, great in villanie,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Thou euer strong vpon the stronger side;

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Thou Fortunes Champion, that do'st neuer fight

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: But when her humourous Ladiship is by

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: To teach thee safety: thou art periur'd too,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: And sooth'st vp greatnesse. What a foole art thou,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: A ramping foole, to brag, and stamp, and sweare,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Vpon my partie: thou cold blooded slaue,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Hast thou not spoke like thunder on my side?

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Beene sworne my Souldier, bidding me depend

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Vpon thy starres, thy fortune, and thy strength,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: And dost thou now fall ouer to my foes?

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: Thou weare a Lyons hide, doff it for shame,

lines.speaker: Const.
lines.text: And hang a Calues skin on those recreant limbes.

lines.speaker: Aus.
lines.text: O that a man should speake those words to me.

lines.speaker: Phil.
lines.text: And hang a Caluesâ€‘skin on those recreant limbs

lines.speaker: Aus.

lines.speaker: Phil.
lines.text: And hang a Caluesâ€‘skin on those recreant limbs.

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: We like not this, thou dost forget thy selfe.

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Heere comes the holy Legat of the Pope.

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: Haile you annointed deputies of heauen;

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: To thee King {% italic: Iohn %} my holy errand is:

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: I {% italic: Pandulph %}, of faire {% italic: Millane %} Cardinall,

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: And from Pope {% italic: Innocent %} the Legate heere,

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: Doe in his name religiously demand

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: Why thou against the Church, our holy Mother,

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: So wilfully dost spurne; and force perforce

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: Keepe {% italic: Stephen Langton %} chosen Archbishop

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: Of {% italic: Canterbury %} from that holy Sea:

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: This in our foresaid holy Fathers name

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: Pope {% italic: Innocent %}, I doe demand of thee.

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: What earthie name to Interrogatories

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Can tast the free breath of a sacred King?

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Thou canst not (Cardinall) deuise a name

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: So slight, vnworthy, and ridiculous

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: To charge me to an answere, as the Pope:

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Tell him this tale, and from the mouth of {% italic: England %},

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Adde thus much more, that no {% italic: Italian %} Priest

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Shall tythe or toll in our dominions:

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: But as we, vnder heauen, are supreame head,

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: So vnder him that great supremacy

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Where we doe reigne, we will alone vphold

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Without th'assistance of a mortall hand:

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: So tell the Pope, all reuerence set apart

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: To him and his vsurp'd athoritie.

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Brother of {% italic: England %}, you blaspheme in this.

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Though you, and all the Kings of Christendom

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Are led so grossely by this medling Priest,

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Dreading the curse that money may buy out,

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: And by the merit of vilde gold, drosse, dust,

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Purchase corrupted pardon of a man,

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Who in that sale sels pardon from himselfe:

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Though you, and al the rest so grossely led,

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: This iugling witchcraft with reuennue cherish,

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Yet I alone, alone doe me oppose

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: Against the Pope, and count his friends my foes.

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Then by the lawfull power that I haue,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Thou shalt stand curst, and excommunicate,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: And blessed shall he be that doth reuolt

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: From his Allegeance to an heretique,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: And meritorious shall that hand be call'd,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Canonized and worship'd as a Saint,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: That takes away by any secret course

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Thy hatefull life.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: O lawfull let it be

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: That I haue roome with Rome to curse a while,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Good Father Cardinall, cry thou Amen

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: To my keene curses; for without my wrong

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: There is no tongue hath power to curse him right.

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: There's Law and Warrant (Lady) for my curse.

lines.speaker: Cons.
lines.text: And for mine too, when Law can do no right.

lines.speaker: Cons.
lines.text: Let it be lawfull, that Law barre no wrong:

lines.speaker: Cons.
lines.text: Law cannot giue my childe his kingdome heere;

lines.speaker: Cons.
lines.text: For he that holds his Kingdome, holds the Law:

lines.speaker: Cons.
lines.text: Therefore since Law it selfe is perfect wrong,

lines.speaker: Cons.
lines.text: How can the Law forbid my tongue to curse?

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: {% italic: Philip %} of {% italic: France %}, on perill of a curse,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Let goe the hand of that Archâ€‘heretique,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: And raise the power of {% italic: France %} vpon his head,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Vnlesse he doe submit himselfe to {% italic: Rome %}.

lines.speaker: Elea.
lines.text: Look'st thou pale {% italic: France %}? do not let go thy hand.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Looke to that Deuill, lest that {% italic: France %} repent,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: And by disioyning hands hell lose a soule.

lines.speaker: Aust.
lines.text: King {% italic: Philip %}, listen to the Cardinall.

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: And hang a Caluesâ€‘skin on his recreant limbs.

lines.speaker: Aust.
lines.text: Well ruffian, I must pocket vp these wrongs,

lines.speaker: Aust.
lines.text: Because,

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: Your breeches best may carry them.

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: {% italic: Philip %}, what saist thou to the Cardinall?

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: What should he say, but as the Cardinall?

lines.speaker: Dolph.
lines.text: Bethinke you father, for the difference

lines.speaker: Dolph.
lines.text: Is purchase of a heauy curse from {% italic: Rome %},

lines.speaker: Dolph.
lines.text: Or the light losse of {% italic: England %}, for a friend:

lines.speaker: Dolph.
lines.text: Forgoe the easier.

lines.speaker: Bla.
lines.text: That s the curse of {% italic: Rome %}.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: O {% italic: Lewis %}, stand fast, the deuill tempts thee heere

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: In likenesse of a new vntrimmed Bride.

lines.speaker: Bla.
lines.text: The Lady {% italic: Constance %} speakes not from her faith,

lines.speaker: Bla.
lines.text: But from her need.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Oh, if thou grant my need,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Which onely liues but by the death of faith,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: That need, must needs inferre this principle,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: That faith would liue againe by death of need:

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: O then tread downe my need, and faith mounts vp,

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: Keepe my need vp, and faith is trodden downe.

lines.speaker: Iohn.
lines.text: The king is moud, and answers not to this.

lines.speaker: Con.
lines.text: O be remou'd from him, and answere well.

lines.speaker: Aust.
lines.text: Doe so king {% italic: Philip %}, hang no more in doubt.

lines.speaker: Bast.
lines.text: Hang nothing but a Calues skin most sweet lout.

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: I am perplext, and know not what to say.

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: What canst thou say, but wil perplex thee more?

lines.speaker: Pan.
lines.text: If thou stand excommunicate, and curst?

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Good reuerend father, make my person yours,

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: And tell me how you would bestow your selfe ?

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: This royall hand and mine are newly knit,

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: And the coniunction of our inward soules

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Married in league, coupled, and link'd together

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: With all religious strength of sacred vowes,

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: The latest breath that gaue the sound of words

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Was deepeâ€‘sworne faith, peace, amity, true loue

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Betweene our kingdomes and our royall selues,

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: And euen before this truce, but new before,

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: No longer then we well could wash our hands,

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: To clap this royall bargaine vp of peace,

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Heauen knowes they were besmear'd and ouerâ€‘staind

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: With slaughters pencill; where reuenge did paint

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: The fearefull difference of incensed kings:

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: And shall these hands so lately purg'd of bloud?

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: So newly ioyn'd in loue? so strong in both,

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Vnyoke this seysure, and this kinde regreete?

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Play fast and loose with faith? so iest with heauen,

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Make such vnconstant children of o ur selues

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: As now againe to snatch our palme from palme:

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Vnâ€‘sweare faith sworne, and on the marriage bed

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Of smiling peace to march a bloody hoast,

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: And make a ryot on the gentle brow

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Of true sincerity? O holy Sir

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: My reuerend father, let it not be so;

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Out of your grace, deuise, ordaine, impose

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: Some gentle order, and then we shall be blest

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: To doe your pleasure, and continue friends.

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: All forme is formelesse, Order orderlesse,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Saue what is opposite to {% italic: Englands %} loue.

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Therefore to Armes, be Champion of our Church,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Or let the Church our mother breathe her curse,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: A mothers curse, on her reuolting sonne:

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: {% italic: France %}, thou maist hold a serpent by the tongue,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: A cased Lion by the mortall paw,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: A fasting Tyger safer by the tooth,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Then keepe in peace that hand which thou dost hold.

lines.speaker: Fra.
lines.text: I may disâ€‘ioyne my hand, but not my faith.

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: So mak'st thou faith an enemy to faith,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: And like a ciuill warre setst oath to oath,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Thy tongue against thy tongue. O let thy vow

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: First made to heauen, first be to heauen perform'd,

lines.speaker: Pand.

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: What since thou sworst, is sworne against thy selfe,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: And may not be performed by thy selfe,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: For that which thou hast sworne to doe amisse,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Is not amisse when it is truly done:

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: And being not done, where doing tends to ill,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: The truth is then most done not doing it:

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: The better Act of purposes mistooke,

lines.speaker: Pand.
lines.text: Is to mistake again, though indirect,
